hotspots.label: Bright Yellow Color
hotspots.fact: This fungus is bright yellow, which helps it stand out in dark, shady places where it grows. The bright color is made by special chemicals inside the organism that help it survive and be noticed by other living things. This is called **pigmentation** — that's when an organism makes colored chemicals to give itself its special color.

vocabulary.definition: The natural color of a living thing, created by special chemicals in its body.

hotspots.label: Spongy Texture
hotspots.fact: This organism has a spongy, bumpy texture that helps it survive in its environment. The spongy parts help the fungus absorb water and nutrients from the dead leaves and wood around it. This special structure is part of its **body structure** — the way an organism's parts are arranged to help it live and grow.

vocabulary.definition: The physical shape and parts of a living thing that help it survive and do what it needs to do.

hotspots.label: Habitat: Dead Plant Matter
hotspots.fact: This yellow fungus lives on dead leaves and wood, which is its **habitat** — the special place where it makes its home. Fungi like this are decomposers, meaning they break down dead plants and return nutrients back to the soil so new plants can grow. This shows how all organisms in an ecosystem are connected and depend on each other!

vocabulary.definition: A living thing that breaks down dead plants and animals, turning them into nutrients that help soil and new life grow.

hotspots.label: Growth and Size
hotspots.fact: Fungi grow by spreading through dead material and creating new fruiting bodies like these bumpy shapes. Each organism starts small and grows bigger as it gets older and stronger. This is part of its **life cycle** — the stages that living things go through as they grow, reproduce, and eventually stop living.

vocabulary.definition: The different stages a living thing goes through during its life, from being born or growing until it dies.
